SectionNotes: This chapter provides guidance for managing new ship acquisitions and the disposal or transfer of vessels from the Company’s management. The aim is to identify potential risks, ensure compliance, and verify the structural and operational integrity of all vessels entering or leaving the fleet.

Objectives: Provide instructions for handling newbuilding project acquisitions.
Define procedures for integrating newly acquired second-hand ships into the Company’s fleet.
Outline the process for ships leaving Company management.
Ensure that all potential risks are identified and addressed.
Verify that all preparatory and inspection activities are correctly completed to confirm no structural or operational defects.

Topics.TopicTitle: Acquisition of New or Second-Hand Ships
Details: All newbuilding and acquisition projects must follow a structured evaluation process before delivery or acceptance.
Inspections ensure the vessel’s compliance with class, flag, and company standards before joining the fleet.
All records, certificates, and manuals must be verified as complete and valid before the vessel’s handover.
Any identified deficiencies must be corrected prior to final acceptance and operation under Company management.

Topics.TopicTitle: Disposal or Release of Ships from Management
Details: When a vessel leaves the Company’s management, all company-specific materials, manuals, and records must be returned or deleted as required.
The Company ensures that no proprietary information or data remains onboard.
All outstanding maintenance, documentation, and statutory obligations must be completed or transferred before release.
A final inspection confirms that the vessel leaves management in satisfactory condition and free from structural or safety deficiencies.

Questions.QuestionText: 1. What is the main purpose of the Acquisition and Disposal of Ships procedure?
Options: A. To regulate ship purchases and disposals only for financial purposes
B. To ensure risks are identified and all preparatory activities are completed properly during acquisition or disposal
C. To document only ship insurance transfers
D. To manage crew change procedures
Questions.Reason: The procedure ensures all potential risks are addressed and preparatory tasks are completed before acquiring or releasing a vessel.

Questions.QuestionText: 2. What must be verified before accepting a new or second-hand ship into the fleet?
Options: A. Only the ship’s cargo capacity
B. All certificates, manuals, and class/flag compliance documentation
C. Only the paint coating condition
D. Crew accommodation layout
Questions.Reason: All official documentation and compliance certificates must be verified to ensure the vessel meets operational and legal standards.

Questions.QuestionText: 3. What happens if deficiencies are identified during the vessel inspection before acquisition?
Options: A. The vessel is accepted as-is
B. The deficiencies must be corrected before final acceptance
C. They are ignored if minor
D. The company proceeds with operations and fixes later
Questions.Reason: Any deficiencies must be corrected before final acceptance to ensure the vessel is compliant and safe to operate.

Questions.QuestionText: 4. What actions must be taken when a ship leaves Company management?
Options: A. Delete company records and ensure no proprietary data remains onboard
B. Retain all company data onboard for reference
C. Leave all manuals for the new owner’s use without review
D. Skip final inspections
Questions.Reason: Company-sensitive data and materials must be removed or returned to maintain confidentiality and compliance.

Questions.QuestionText: 5. Why is a final inspection performed before a vessel’s release from management?
Options: A. To check the ship’s financial valuation
B. To confirm the vessel is free from structural or safety deficiencies
C. To evaluate crew performance
D. To update office records only
Questions.Reason: The final inspection ensures the ship leaves management in a safe, defect-free condition and in compliance with company standards.

Questions.QuestionText: 6. What is required before finalizing a newbuilding project or ship acquisition?
Options: A. Class and flag inspection approvals with all documentation verified
B. Only verbal approval from the superintendent
C. Signing of commercial contracts only
D. Postponement of inspection until after sailing
Questions.Reason: Formal class and flag approvals, along with documentation verification, are mandatory before a vessel can be accepted into the fleet.
